data.title: Fix property warnings and hide some debug prints
data.body:
"ALL IS GOOD" was a lie.

In particular, removes verbose "path not recognized" false positive.

The actual logic is to (somewhat naively) check all ResourceFormatLoaders
and to pick the first good match, so no need to warn about the formats
that do not match the type hint.

I debugged it this way to be sure:
```
diff --git a/core/io/resource_loader.cpp b/core/io/resource_loader.cpp
index 2a6e60d..baa2e3f 100644
--- a/core/io/resource_loader.cpp
+++ b/core/io/resource_loader.cpp
@@ -181,9 +181,26 @@ RES ResourceLoader::load(const String &p_path, const String &p_type_hint, bool p
 
 	for (int i = 0; i < loader_count; i++) {
 
+		print_line("------");
 		if (!loader[i]->recognize_path(local_path, p_type_hint)) {
-			print_line("path not recognized: " + local_path);
+			print_line("BAD: path NOT recognized: '" + local_path + "' as '" + p_type_hint + "'");
+			print_line("while trying ResourceFormatLoader " + itos(i));
+
+			List<String> extensions;
+			loader[i]->get_recognized_extensions(&extensions);
+			for (List<String>::Element *E = extensions.front(); E; E = E->next()) {
+				print_line("Extensions: " + E->get());
+			}
 			continue;
+		} else {
+			print_line("GOOD: path recognized: '" + local_path + "' as '" + p_type_hint + "'");
+			print_line("while trying ResourceFormatLoader " + itos(i));
+
+			List<String> extensions;
+			loader[i]->get_recognized_extensions(&extensions);
+			for (List<String>::Element *E = extensions.front(); E; E = E->next()) {
+				print_line("Extensions: " + E->get());
+			}
 		}
 		found = true;
 		RES res = loader[i]->load(local_path, local_path, r_error);
```
```
------
BAD: path NOT recognized: 'res://ball.png' as 'Texture'
while trying ResourceFormatLoader 0
Extensions: tscn
Extensions: tres
------
BAD: path NOT recognized: 'res://ball.png' as 'Texture'
while trying ResourceFormatLoader 1
Extensions: po
------
```

There might be a cleverer way to bind specific type hints to the proper loader than trying them all and picking the first match, but it does the job so far :)

data.title: Exporter saves Particles2D as Node2D on 3.x scene file
data.body:
**Ubuntu 17.04 - Godot version: 2.1.3**


**Issue description:**
The exporter turns Particles2D into Node2D on the scene file.

It was expected to have them saved as Particles2D.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Export to 3.0 a 2.x project with particles (like the demo) and then open the tscn file with a text editor.

data.title: Godot 3 Particle Curves *Fixnum Build*
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Windows 64-bit

**Issue description:**

Tried selecting the points in the 3d particle scale curve editor. Each time could only make points beside the point I was trying to select. Sometimes I could select a point, but most of the time it just created new points as I tried to select one.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Create a 3d particle system. Set your mesh. Set your particle material. Go into the scale curve editor. Select either point at the beginning or the end. It will make new points instead most of the time. Try to create a point in the middle of the curve. Now try to select it. Most of the time all you can do is create a new point beside it or on top of it.

Possible issue is that the selection area is way too small.

data.title: GDNative: ability to handle "editor" and "export" versions of a library
data.body:
Currently GDNative allows only one version of a library for each platform, however it would be good for it to also support a version that will be used in editor with debug checks and messages (eventually editor tools), and have an optimized version of the library being used when it gets exported.

The first idea I have in mind is basically doubling the amount of paths to setup (per platform per mode), having one of them optional if the library doesn't need to. Another idea would be to use a naming convention.

data.title: Adding Python-like max(), min(), all(), any() in GDScript
data.body:
**Issue description:**
It would be really nice to manipulate with GDScript arrays using max(), min()(instead of current min/max that takes only two floats), all() and any().
I know, that these functions are O(n) complexity, but still...

data.title: Fix template loading
data.body:
Template loading was broken for Windows and Linux, even with custom templates it disabled the export button if default templates were not found. 

Also with binary type = 64 bits and only 64 bit templates present it still disabled the export.
This fixes said errors, although a fair cleanup of `editor_export.cpp` is due, a large part of it is `#if 0`'ed away and the code to fix this was actually there, just dead.

Just found 96de0141ccef3bb035574010816dafdbfc17eb63 which does that and states that the import / export system is due a rewrite, well hope this fix helps in the meantime.

data.title: Buffer overflow when instancing 14563 PackedScene.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux - Ubuntu Mate 16.10 - Godot 2.1.2 stable

**Issue description:**
I was facing an over usage of RAM with my Godot 2D game prototype, and I decided to find the cause of it. I wanted to see how many PackedScene instance Godot could handle without blowing out my RAM.

I built a main scene with a simple architecture:
```
---> Node // Script attached  here
       +----> YSort
```
I built also a scene called "Hexa.tscn", with a simple architecture too:
```
---> Area2D
       +-----> Sprite
```

In a script attached to the root node of the main scene I try to add as much "Hexa" scene instance as possible in the YSort Node.

If I add 14562 Hexa scene instances, everything goes well (~3% usage of 1 CPU, ~115Mo RAM usage, that represents: 29655 Objects, 3 Resources, 29127 Nodes)

But if I add **14563** Hexa scene instances, I encounter a buffer overflow error, as follow:

In the Error tab of the debugger:
```
Type: Error
Description:
Time: 0:00:00:0458
C Error: Condition '(buffer_end+room_needed) >= buffer_size' is true. returned ERR_OUT_OF_MEMORY
C Source: core/message_queue.ccp:54
C function: push_call
```
In the Output tab of the debugger:
```
failed method: Sprite:_update_callback target ID: 29681
TOTAL BYTES: 1048560
NULL count: 0
CALL _sort_children: 14564
CALL_update_callback: 29126
```

Is this a bug ?

**Steps to reproduce:**
Run  the attached Godot project in Godot editor to see the error in the debugger.

**Link to minimal example project:**
[memtest.tar.gz](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/948020/memtest.tar.gz)

data.title: set_shader_param do not ignore capitalization
data.body:
I recently [discovered](https://godotengine.org/qa/14234/automatically-loading-normal-from-paths-normal-appearing) that the inspector auto-capitalizes all property labels (thanks @eons), but my shader variable was simply "normal". This led to scripting issues when I tried to reference the variable by what I saw in the inspector - `get_material().set_shader_param("Normal", load(normal_map_png_path))`. I had to use the string "normal" instead. 

To fix this, inspector capitalization could match parameter capitalization, or variants could ignore capitalization and make all reference strings lowercase before searching. I doubt someone would be using "Normal" and "normal" params on the same object, they certainly shouldn't be.

data.title: Changing the remote debugging icon
data.body:
I recently came across this [QA thread](https://godotengine.org/qa/6769/how-to-show-some-debugging-information-when-we-run-the-game) which says to click the debug icon in the top icon panel. It took me at least 30s to find the icon they were talking about - it's the far right icon. I haven't seen this icon before, what's it supposed to be?

![selection_085](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7429786/25280212/249ec424-2677-11e7-929c-50367454df44.png)

I think this could be communicated better to users. Would it be possible to change this to a little bug icon instead? I found some options [here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3081106/where-can-i-get-a-good-set-of-ide-icons), [here](http://game-icons.net/) and [here](http://www.flaticon.com/search?word=bug&license=all&color=0&stroke=0).

data.body:
Looks like get_model_name is only implemented on Android.

Will look into implementing it on iOS, not 100% sure but implementing this may do the trick:
https://developer.apple.com/reference/uikit/uidevice/1620044-model

data.title: Expose PoolArray Read and Write to GDNative
data.body:
GDNative has currently only one Godotian way to fill an array and send it to the engine, which is to use one of the existing PoolArrays (Vector2, Vector3, Int, Float...), resize it, and assign every index one by one just like GDScript.
Problem: doing this frequently with many elements is inefficient, which is why Read and Write structures exist in C++ so that multiples values can be read or modified in one efficient transaction (unless I misunderstand them?).
However these structures aren't available to GDNative.
Having them in the API would speed up data transfer for procedural generation of meshes, signal processing or other tasks requiring to read or write in one of those arrays (especially Mesh generation in my case).

data.title: Enhancement Request: Editor doesn't remember which workspace was used/opened across scenes.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 x64 - Godot 2.1.3 (Latest)


**Issue description:**
Whenever I open a workspace and I switch scenes it doesn't gets saved and the editor won't remember which one I had opened before on a previous scene, e.g. I open the 2D Workspace on Scene A on Tab A, I switch to Scene B on Tab B and open the Script Workspace, I switch back to Scene A on Tab A and the Workspace currently selected will be the one I had previously selected on Scene B on Tab B, so I have to manually change Workspace across tabs or scenes.


**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a new Scene, let's call it Scene A
2. Create a new Scene, let's call it Scene B
3. On Scene A, open the 2D Workspace.
4. On Scene B, open the Script Workspace.
5. While on Scene B, Switch to Scene A, the Workspace from Scene B will still be selected.
6. On Scene A, Switch Workspace to 2D.
7. While on Scene A, Switch to Scene B, the Workspace from Scene A will still be selected.

Here's a more visual description: https://puu.sh/vqAIA/9e7085820a.mp4

**Link to minimal example project:**
N/A

data.title: Debugging / live editing a project running on another PC.
data.body:
I was wondering if there is a way to debug a project running on a another PC. I cannot find a way in the editor, and, looking at the code, it seems that there are only two ways to do remote debugging:

1) Forking a new instance of the editor, letting it run the current project and having it connect back to the main editor. [editor_run.cpp]

2) Deploying the project to a supported export platform (e.g. Android), using a platform-specific communication channel (e.g. adb). [editor_run_native.cpp]

But I am fairly new to the code-base and maybe I've missed it. If there is no way, I'd like to start a discussion about implementing it.

data.title: Image size in vram reported is many times larger of it's original size
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1 official linux kubuntu 16.10

**Issue description:**
When looking at reported image size in video memory it reports allocated memory in chunks from 3x and up of it's size.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open project with any PNG images in scene. 
2. Open debugger "video memory" tab and hit refresh
3. Compare size of original image with reported size of allocated space for it in debugger. 

Example: Godot project icon size is 2kb. When loaded in the game it's 16 kb. 1900x1000 something screenshot is 1.3 mb. When loaded in the game it's reported size is 12 mb.

data.title: Godot 3.0 bad default snake_case results with classes that have 2D in the name
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
3.0 alpha

**Issue description:**
If you enable snake_case, and add for example "CollisionShape2D", it turns into "collision_shape2_d".
What is expected is "collision_shape_2d". 


**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Turn on snake_case
2. Add CollisionShape2D.
